Description.val:
The FY 2021 funding request was reduced by $3.000 million to account for the availability of prior year execution balances.

PROGRAM COVERAGE: Surveillance Towed Array Sensor System (SURTASS) is the mobile, tactical, and strategic arm of the Navy's undersea surveillance capability that provides deep ocean and littoral acoustic detection and cueing for tactical weapon platforms against diesel and nuclear submarines as well as surface vessels in any given Area of Operations worldwide.  Dedicated Anti-Submarine Warfare (ASW) T-AGOS ships tow long acoustic arrays that collect acoustic data and relay that data to shore facilities via satellites for processing and fusion of the resulting contact data with other sensors.  Currently, there are five Small Waterplane Area Twin Hull (SWATH) T-AGOS ships operating in the Pacific area.  Ship configurations are:
 
T-AGOS 22 USNS LOYAL (1), a SWATH-P platform which supports passive operations using the TB-29A Twinline (TL-29A) array, providing improved detection and classification capability. This ship class uses the Integrated Common Processor (ICP) signal processing and display system common with the SSN Advanced Rapid Commercial Off the Shelf (COTS) Insertion (ARCI) Sonar Processing System;  

Three (3) T-AGOS SWATH-P platforms, T-AGOS 19 USNS VICTORIOUS, T-AGOS 20 USNS ABLE, and T-AGOS 21 USNS EFFECTIVE, supporting passive/active operations, configured with the ICP processing and display system, the TL-29A array, and the Compact Low Frequency Active (CLFA) transmit capability;

One (1) Low Frequency Active (LFA) equipped ship, T-AGOS 23 USNS IMPECCABLE, a SWATH-A platform configured with the ICP processing and display system, the TL-29A array, and the Low Frequency Active (LFA) transmit capability. The active capability provides greatly improved detection against diesel submarines as well as the quiet nuclear submarine threat.
 
In addition to the five platforms described above, two (2) shore sites are configured with the ICP processing and display suites to receive the T-AGOS acoustic data via SHF satellite communication links.  One of the two shore sites is equipped with three (3) SURTASS Team Trainers (STTs) to support Home Port Training Periods.  

A cost sharing agreement with Japan also provides a shore site and two Japanese SWATH ships with similar capability to the T-AGOS SWATH-P ships for the Western Pacific region.  The Japanese Auxiliary Ocean Surveillance (JAOS) ships have been upgraded to the TL-29A array. A third Japanese SWATH ship is planned for delivery in 2021 with mission equipment funding previously programmed.

The Expeditionary Surveillance Towed Array Sensor System (SURTASS-E) provides a SURTASS passive capability packaged in ISO-Vans (ISO-International Organization for Standardization) for mobilization on Vessels of Opportunity (VOOs).  It was developed as a Rapid Prototyping, Experimentation, and Demonstration (RPED) project, tasked to re-package, test, and demonstrate an expeditionary variant of the passive component of the SURTASS acoustic surveillance system that can be used as a surrogate for some of the SURTASS capabilities provided by traditional T-AGOS class vessels.

The primary reason for the increase in funding for FY21 and succeeding years is to support the procurement of four SURTASS-E RPED units, one each in FY21, FY22, FY24, and FY25. These SURTASS-E mission system shipsets consist of the towed array and winch set, ISO-Van/SURTASS Operations Center (SOC) integration set, ICP Processing set, Mission system integration set, and C4I set. These mission systems will be procured during these timeframes based upon initial non-recurring engineering efforts and vessel of opportunity (VOO) configuration evaluations accomplished under prior-year ONR RDTEN funding.

[P3A - 6 / VG007 - Field Changes/Modifications]: VG007
Field Changes/Modifications - Provides for correction of deficiencies identified by Fleet use, array support equipment, communications equipment, and replacement of aging/unsupportable equipment.

VG776
Installation of Equipment - Installation Agents: NIWC LANT, NIWC PAC, Military Sealift Command, and Lockheed Martin.

Justification.val: FY21 requests funding for Integrated Common Processor (ICP) units ($10.81M), $1.02M for additional TL-29A towed array refurbishments, $1.75M for SURTASS Team Trainers, $46.45M for an additional SURTASS-E system, and $3.82M for field changes and modifications for multi-year transition to an upgraded command and control (C2) system.  Details provided in individual exhibit P-3As.

Name.@footnote: ICP system configuration varies from ship to ship depending upon the type of arrays used (passive only, or passive and active).  Additionally, Tech refresh efforts and individual unit procurements and their related costs can be more significant in some years than others based on a wide range of factors, including end of life components that require refresh; the combination of Low Frequency Active (LFA) vs. Compact Low Frequency Active (CLFA) assets; the need to incorporate significant cyber security and program protection improvements to reduce existing and projected threat vectors as well as the overall program protection posture and related requirements; inspections and testing into a particular ICP system undergoing refresh; and the need to update Configuration Control Models (CCMs) or Engineering Measurements Program (EMP) systems for each major hardware refresh.  Accordingly, the procurement and installation costs will vary from one platform to another, depending on the configuration and the ship.   To elaborate, the unit cost adjustment from FY20 to FY21 is not merely an inflation increase. This additional funding is required to accomplish the combined active/passive ICP variants and their related refresh efforts required in FY21. Due to the additional requirements associated with the FY21 units, particularly the need to update Configuration Control Models (CCMs) and Engineering Measurements Program (EMP) systems for each of the major hardware refreshes accomplished in FY21, unit costs increased approximately 25% in FY21. Cyber security requirements and program protection requirements are increasing, becoming more labor-intensive and hardware based, and demand that more frequent mitigation efforts be put into place. Additionally, the TI20 equipment that we plan to field in FY21 and FY22 provides additional computing power and storage necessary to support new capabilities, e.g., full array processing, in order to modernize the system to meet increasingly demanding Fleet requirements.

ImplementationMethodName.val: AIT (Alteration Installation Team):: Installation Name: Integrated Common Processor

Description.val:
FY21 and out-year funding continues cyclical ICP technical refresh of hardware and software.

ICP system configuration varies from ship to ship depending upon the type of arrays used (passive only, or passive and active).  Additionally, Tech refresh efforts and individual unit procurements and their related costs can be more significant in some years than others based on a wide range of factors, including end of life components that require refresh; the combination of Low Frequency Active (LFA) vs. Compact Low Frequency Active (CLFA) assets; the need to incorporate significant cyber security and program protection improvements to reduce existing and projected threat vectors as well as the overall program protection posture and related requirements; inspections and testing into a particular ICP system undergoing refresh; and the need to update Configuration Control Models (CCMs) or Engineering Measurements Program (EMP) systems for each major hardware refresh.  Accordingly, the procurement and installation costs will vary from one platform to another, depending on the configuration and the ship.

ImplementationMethodName.val: AIT (Alteration Installation Team):: Installation Name: SURTASS-E Arrays

Description.val: The Expeditionary Surveillance Towed Array Sensor System (SURTASS-E) provides a SURTASS passive capability packaged in ISO-Vans (ISO-International Organization for Standardization) for mobilization on Vessels of Opportunity (VOOs). It was developed as a Rapid Prototyping, Experimentation, and Demonstration (RPED) project, tasked to re-package, test, and demonstrate an expeditionary variant of the passive component of the SURTASS acoustic surveillance system that can be used as a surrogate for some of the SURTASS capabilities provided by traditional T-AGOS class vessels. The $10M in FY19 provided for procurement of a production TL-29A Twin Line Towed Array plus supporting towed array assemblies and components for the SURTASS-E RPED system, required to support extended testing and development. Additional funding was added to FY21, FY22, FY24, and FY25 for procurement of one (1) production SURTASS-E system per year, with deliveries nominally planned 19 months after each procurement.  Equipment to be delivered is initially provided as ready assets, and installed as needed.

Name.@footnote: The TL-29A Twinline is a shallow water variant of the common array produced by NAVSEA.  The array consists of two shorter array lengths and array support equipment, and is designed for increased surveillance capability in high clutter environments and littoral areas.  Support equipment procurement is for ancillary test sets, array headline and roll control systems, tow cable, and leader cables. Installation funding is not required for the support equipment.  FY20-FY24 funds refurbishment of one (1) array leg per year, which is less costly than procurement of new arrays.  Installation Remarks:  Installation occurs on five T-AGOS platforms and a TASW SURTASS platform.  Historically, an array is lost or severely damaged every 18-24 months.  The arrays require constant refurbishment and/or parts replacement due to the harsh environmental conditions encountered.  Without a ready asset in theater, if an array is lost or damaged, a SURTASS ship cannot deploy and execute its mission.  Future assets to be delivered are initially provided as ready assets, and installed as needed.

ImplementationMethodName.val: AIT (Alteration Installation Team):: Installation Name: U.S. Twinline Arrays

Description.val: The TL-29A Twinline is a shallow water variant of the common array produced by NAVSEA.  The array consists of two (2) shorter array lengths and array support equipment, and is designed for increased surveillance capability in high clutter environments and littoral areas.  Funding in FY21-FY25 is provided to refurbish existing TL-29A array legs. Support equipment includes ancillary test sets, array headline and roll control systems, tow cables, and array leader cables.

ImplementationMethodName.val: AIT (Alteration Installation Team):: Installation Name: J-AOS

Description.val: The J-AOS TL-29A procurement costs are associated with upgrading to a new array type and array support infrastructure, including two complete towed arrays and associated tow hardware and dry end equipment.  A third rotational pool array, modules, dry side equipment and support equipment procurement was moved from FY21 to FY19.  A third J-AOS ship is being constructed with commissioning scheduled for FY21.  The ship requires outfitting with a mission system with procurement of a TL-29A array system and associated tow hardware, dry end equipment and installation.  The program is funded with both FMS and OPN, and the $15M in FY17 and the $8.754M in FY19 represent the U.S. share of the total cost of the J-AOS TL-29A upgrade program.   The U.S. cost share for the outfitting of the new J-AOS platform (J-3) is $19.6M. All installation costs are paid via FMS funds.

ImplementationMethodName.val: AIT (Alteration Installation Team):: Installation Name: SURTASS Team Trainer

Description.val:
The SURTASS Team Trainer (STT) provides SURTASS crews with three high fidelity synthetic and live playback training capabilities to support Home Port Training Periods (HPTP) and Pre-Deployment Certification Periods (PDCP).  Each STT will receive a hardware tech refresh on a six-year cycle and receive a major software update installation on a two-year cycle, so that 3 STTs hardware tech refreshes and 9 major software installations would be performed over a given six-year period.  Tech refresh and software updates for the STTs will continue on this cycle.
The 4-7% procurement cost growth between FY18, FY20, FY22, and FY24 accounts for the additional STT capabilities incorporated to provide operators with the means to address more sophisticated threat targets and environments.

ImplementationMethodName.val: AIT (Alteration Installation Team):: Installation Name: Field Changes/Modifications

Description.val:
Field Changes/Modifications for correction of deficiencies identified by Fleet use, array support, communications equipment and replacement of aging/unsupportable equipment. Additional FY21-FY25 funding will facilitate transition to an upgraded command and control system, including installation of the Consolidated Afloat Network Enterprise System (CANES). Other aging End-of-life systems, including Global Command and Control System-Maritime (GCCS-M), UHF Line-of-sight Satellite (LOS/SAT), and ship's gyros will need to be replaced in order to ensure continuity of operations should the primary acoustic path to shore become inoperable.
C4I system configurations being procured vary, resulting in the variability in individual unit costs across the fiscal years.
